fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Brotherston in [brotherston2005] uses the idea of "folding up" the infinite representation of a cyclic proof to obtain equivalent cyclic proofs in cyclic normal form. The folding process essentially annotates a rule graph (that is a "subtree" of the infinte unfolding) with some cycles.
The notion of root-preserving surjective rule graph homomorphism is used to describe mappings between rule graphs that describe the same infinite proofs.

One problem with this (for our use-case) is that this notion does not consider cycles since they are not part of the rule graph data. Also as far as I can tell, the fact that this kind of homomorphism does not only operate at the level of cyclic tree structure, and deals with strict equality of sequents and rules (call these "tree labels") means that it is not generalisable to systems where cycles may be formed up-to other conditions, e.g. substitution or weakening. The equitable partition approach looks like it would generalise the "equality of tree labels" requirement of the homomorphism nicely.

In our use-case, we care about studying the unfoldings of a cyclic proof that are generated "bottom up", i.e. from an existing cyclic proof to a "larger" unfolding. This is in contrast to the "top down" approach - taking the unique infinite unfolding and folding it up to a smaller, finitely-presented proof in some way.

fr:title.text: Leigh and Wehr's notion of unfolding

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Leigh and Wehr's notion of unfolding

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Leigh and Wehr in [leighwehr2023] define unfolding at the level of labelled cyclic trees. By disregarding the tree labels (sequents and rules) their definition also works for cyclic trees.
Their unfolding definition covers the "basic" unfoldings that we have considered i.e. those where you unfold a single cycle, and you link the new bud back to either the old companion or the old bud.

As far as I can tell, this definition does not properly extend the cycle map \beta with cycles created by unfolding, apart from that of the one bud that is being unfolded. There is not just one obvious way to do this, so there is definitely something missing in the definition here: a natural way is for newly created buds to link back to the companions for the buds they are copies of.
I think that this notion of unfolding is the closest to what we want to define.

fr:title.text: Sprenger and Dam's notion of unfolding

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sprenger and Dam's notion of unfolding

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Sprenger and Dam's unfolding algorithm in [sprengerdam2003] was developed to find a tree-dischargeable version of a given cyclic proof.

fr:p.html:mark: TODO: Needs discussing: Intuitively, a tree-dischargeable proof \mathcal P is one where the structural dependancy ordering \leq _{\mathcal P} of cycles can be mapped monotonically into a given tree-like partial order \preccurlyeq .

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The algorithm operates in the "bottom up" direction, taking an existing (injective) cyclic proof \mathcal {P}_0 and unfolding it iteratively. It also does not refer to the sequents or rules associated with nodes in the cyclic proof, instead operating solely at the level of cyclic trees and keeping track of repeated nodes by tagging them with a copy number. Importantly, the algorithm assumes that an induction order discharging \mathcal {P}_0 is given to deal with how new cycles are defined during unfolding.

fr:title.text: Ideas for cyclic proof theory research

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideas for cyclic proof theory research

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since it seems hard to imbue our cyclic proof system with a well-behaved notion of computation (specifically one that works nicely alongside \forall reductions), maybe a change of perspective is required. We could instead work with a reset proof system analogue of \mu HOL^{ex} and try to add a notion of computation to reset proofs.
I first need to understand reset proof systems to see if they are suitable for tackling this problem.

Things working up to this and related things I would like to try:
Do an "Abstract cyclic proofs" treatment of reset proof systems and try to show that the abstractions are related somehow
Look at a reset proof system version of a simpler proof system, i.e. Viswanathan and Viswanathan's HO fixed-point logic [viswanathanviswanathan2004]
A literature review on reset proof systems (currently I only know about Dominik Wehr's licentiate thesis, but this should link to other papers)
See if the \mu HOL^{ex} trace condition can be represented as an activation algebra. If not, perhaps there is some other class of trace category that encompasses trace conditions like ours?

fr:title.text: Ideas for cycle reduction in HOL^{ex}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideas for cycle reduction in \mu HOL^{ex}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We are (still) working out how we can equip cycles with a notion of reduction or "unfolding". We specifically want the property that we can "unfold" a cycle and then replace a free variable along the cycle with some term without breaking the well-formedness of the cycle: lets call this property A.

We've found a criteria that the substitutions along cycles have to satisfy to allow us to "unfold" them in a way that has property A - that is the requirement that each variable is either substituted by itself or a fresh variable w.r.t. the companion sequent. Call this property P. P(\theta , B, C) := \forall x \in \text {fv}(C) . \theta (x) = x \vee \theta (x) \notin \text {fv}(C) If this holds, then we can "unfold" the cycle just once and the resulting proof has property A. If this doesn't hold, the current idea is to translate the proof to a different one where the cycle in question has property P.
The translation revolves around the idea of replacing \mu -formulae with semantically equivalent ones that interact with the free variables of the sequent in subtle way.

fr:title.text: Methods of obtaining distributive law results

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Methods of obtaining distributive law results

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
I've been reviewing the literature on distributive laws, specifically those papers that Dan Marsden mentioned, and have found some candidates for methods that we could attempt to adapt to finding monad container distributive laws:
Generalising the "abides" property in [zwartmarsden2022] to monad containers - looks like it would be some funky equation on positions in \sigma shapes.
Manes and Mulry I Theorem 4.3.4 mentions something about distributive laws between commutative monads - this might be adaptable.
"Multiple constants" in [zwartmarsden2022] would correspond to multiple shapes having singleton position sets.
Manes and Mulry use "Kleisli strengths" to show distributive laws, we should see what those are in the case of monad containers.
I am a PhD student at Royal Holloway, University of London researching programming language semantics via cyclic proof theory, type theory, and category theory.
\mu HOL^{ex} is a logic and cyclic proof system that I've been developing for part of my PhD project with my supervisor Reuben Rowe.

The goal is to develop a proof system for higher-order logic with fixed-point operators, that allows for induction and coinduction by adding fixed-point "unfolding" rules, and allowing proofs to be cyclic.

Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as \mathbf {Set} functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.
By combining the work of Ahman and Uustalu on distributive laws for directed containers and our work, it is also easy enough to characterise mixed distributive laws.
This website uses the Forester tool developed by Jon Sterling. See Jon's website for tutorials/information about the tool.
It is a fantastic way to organise notes and I've been enjoying it a lot! There is even a VSCode plugin.
